subSections.title: 1.1.1 Images and Graphics
subSections.content: Provide text alternatives for all non-text content including images, icons, and graphics. Use alt attributes that accurately describe the purpose or content of the image.

subSections.title: 1.1.2 Audio and Video
subSections.content: Include captions for videos and transcripts for audio content. This ensures users who are deaf or hard of hearing can access multimedia content.

subSections.title: 1.1.3 Data Visualizations
subSections.content: Ensure charts, graphs, and infographics have text descriptions explaining the key information they convey. Complex data should be available in alternative accessible formats.

subSections.title: 1.2.1 Responsive Design
subSections.content: Create layouts that adapt to different screen sizes and orientations. Content should be viewable without requiring horizontal scrolling at standard zoom levels.

subSections.title: 1.2.2 Color and Contrast
subSections.content: Ensure sufficient contrast between text and background colors. Never use color alone to convey information, as users with color blindness may miss these cues.

subSections.title: 1.2.3 Text Resizing
subSections.content: Allow text to be resized up to 200% without loss of content or functionality. Use relative units like em or rem instead of fixed pixel sizes.

subSections.title: 2.1.1 Keyboard Navigation
subSections.content: Ensure all functionality is available using only a keyboard. Users with motor disabilities often rely on keyboards or keyboard alternatives rather than mice.

subSections.title: 2.1.2 Focus Management
subSections.content: Maintain a visible focus indicator when navigating with a keyboard. The tab order should follow a logical sequence that matches the visual layout.

subSections.title: 2.1.3 Keyboard Traps
subSections.content: Avoid keyboard traps where users can tab into an element but cannot tab away from it. This prevents users from navigating through the entire interface.

subSections.title: 2.2.1 Time Limits
subSections.content: Provide options to extend or remove time limits on interactions. Some users with disabilities may need more time to complete tasks or read content.

subSections.title: 2.2.2 Moving Content
subSections.content: Allow users to pause, stop, or hide any moving, blinking, or auto-updating content. This helps users who have difficulty tracking moving objects or get distracted easily.

subSections.title: 2.3.1 Flashing Content
subSections.content: Avoid content that flashes more than three times per second, as this can trigger seizures in people with photosensitive epilepsy.

subSections.title: 3.1.1 Clear Language
subSections.content: Use clear, simple language appropriate for the content. Avoid jargon and complex terminology when possible, or provide definitions when specialized terms are necessary.

subSections.title: 3.1.2 Language Identification
subSections.content: Specify the primary language of the page and indicate changes in language within content. This helps screen readers pronounce content correctly.

subSections.title: 3.2.1 Consistent Navigation
subSections.content: Maintain consistent navigation patterns throughout the site. Users should be able to predict where to find navigation elements on each page.

subSections.title: 3.2.2 Predictable Interactions
subSections.content: Make sure components with the same functionality look and behave consistently. Avoid surprising users with unexpected changes when they interact with elements.

subSections.title: 3.3.1 Error Identification
subSections.content: Clearly identify input errors and provide descriptive error messages. Users should understand what went wrong and how to fix it.

subSections.title: 3.3.2 Form Labels and Instructions
subSections.content: Provide clear labels and instructions for form fields. Include examples of expected formats for data entry when applicable.

subSections.title: 4.1.1 Valid Markup
subSections.content: Use valid, well-formed HTML to ensure compatibility with current and future browsers, assistive technologies, and other user agents.

subSections.title: 4.1.2 Name, Role, Value
subSections.content: Ensure that all interface components have appropriate names, roles, and values that can be programmatically determined by assistive technologies.

subSections.title: 4.1.3 Status Messages
subSections.content: Communicate status changes and dynamic content updates to assistive technologies without disrupting the user's current focus.

subSections.title: 4.2.1 Progressive Enhancement
subSections.content: Build with a layered approach that provides a basic experience to all users, then enhances the experience for users with more capable browsers or devices.

subSections.title: 4.2.2 Testing Across Platforms
subSections.content: Test your content with different browsers, devices, and assistive technologies to ensure broad compatibility and accessibility.
